Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: Making assumptions about type parameters?: :I want to subclass Iterator into what I'll call FooIterator. My code looks something like this:public class FooIterator<E> implements Iterator<E> {  public FooIterator(Collection<Bar> bars) {    innerIterator = bars.iterator();  }  @Override  public boolean hasNext() {    return innerIterator.hasNext();  }  @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")  @Override  public E next() {    Bar bar = innerIterator.next();    return new E(bar);  }  @Override  public void remove() {    throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Don't remove from FooIterator!");  }  private Iterator<Bar> innerIterator;}...except, of course, this doesn't work because I can't instantiate a new E from a Bar.I would only ever use this with an E that has a constructor that takes a Bar. Is there any way to "prove" that to the compiler, or to just throw a runtime error if E doesn't have an appropriate constructor?Or perhaps I'm just not using the right design pattern here? I've been doing a lot of C++ recently, and I feel like I might be approaching this the wrong way.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.

Question: How can I create a custom Iterator that only iterates over a subset of a Collection?
Please using this api: Collections.unmodifiableCollection.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Collections.unmodifiableCollection
<<<code>>>: Collection<Bar> subset = Collections.unmodifiableCollection(bars.stream().filter(bar -> bar.isSubset()).collect(Collectors.toList()));
<<<explanation>>>: The unmodifiableCollection() method of the Collections class returns a new unmodifiable collection backed by the specified collection.
Question: How can I create a read-only view of a collection?
Please using this api: Collections.unmodifiableCollection.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Collections.unmodifiableCollection
<<<code>>>: Collection<E> subset = Collections.unmodifiableCollection(bars.stream().filter(bar -> bar.isSubset()).collect(Collectors.toList()));
<<<explanation>>>: The unmodifiableCollection() method of the Collections class returns a new unmodifiable collection backed by the specified collection.
Question: How can I filter a collection based on a predicate?
Please using this api: Stream.filter.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Stream.filter
<<<code>>>: Collection<E> subset = bars.stream().filter(bar -> bar.isSubset()).collect(Collectors.toList());
<<<explanation>>>: The filter() method of the Stream interface returns a Stream consisting of the elements that match the given predicate.
Question: How can I convert a Stream to a Collection?
Please using this api: Stream.collect.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Stream.collect
<<<code>>>: Collection<E> subset = bars.stream().filter(bar -> bar.isSubset()).collect(Collectors.toList());
<<<explanation>>>: The collect() method of the Stream interface performs a mutable reduction operation on the elements of this stream.
Question: How can I create a list from a stream?
Please using this api: Stream.collect.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Stream.collect
<<<code>>>: List<E> subset = bars.stream().filter(bar -> bar.isSubset()).collect(Collectors.toList());
<<<explanation>>>: The collect() method of the Stream interface performs a mutable reduction operation on the elements of this stream. The toList() collector returns a list containing the elements of the stream.
